First haircut...Big step. I am glad your little one took it well. 
 
 We had an exciting first here last night, too. First M&M up the nose. My 2 yr old came in rubbing here nose. The conversation went something like this:
 
 "Whats wrong with your nose hon?"
 
 "M&M in nose"
 
 "You have an M&M in your nose?"
 
 "Yes"
 
 At this point I obtained visual conformation that there was in fact a yellow M&M lodged securely in the left nostril.
 
 "Why did you put an M&M in your nose?"
 
 "Momma did it."
 
 "Your mother put an M&M in your nose?"
 
 "Yes"
 
 "I don't think momma did it. Did you put the M&M in your nose?"
 
 "Yes"
 
 I have found from past experiences that asking foolish questions like "why would you do somehting that rediculous" get you nowhere. Just accept the fact that the M&M is in the nose and move on.
 
 I held her down on the couch and blew in her mouth (a trick I learned from an ER doctor when I once transported a 3 yr old to the ER with a nostril full of styrofoam packing beads) and the snotty M&M shot right out. 
 
 The thrills of being a parent.

Anastasia,
 
 Have you ever done the rouge test with your little boy? It involves using a mirror and some make-up to demonstrate the development of self-awareness during infancy. 
 
 Since it is right around 16-20 months that infants start to become acutely self-aware (a major developmental milestone that preceeds true emotion) I bet that your son was having one heck of an time understanding what was going on between the mirror and his head. That could be why he looked so serious -- he had a lot on his mind. 
 
 Development in action--so common but so extraordinary at the same time.
